h i g h l i g h t s
Addition of MS (micro-silica) or NS (nano-silica) enhances strength and durability. Combined addition of MS and NS offers synergistic effects in sulphate resistance and carbonation resistance. Combined addition of MS and NS offers additive effects in chloride resistance and water resistance. NS should be added together with MS for production of new generation high-performance concrete.

a b s t r a c t
To investigate the combined effects of micro-silica (MS) and nano-silica (NS) on the durability of concrete, an experimental program was launched, in which mortar mixes representing mortar portions of concrete with various water, MS and NS contents but a constant workability were made for strength, sulphate attack, carbonation, rapid chloride permeability and water absorption tests. It was found that the addition of MS and/or NS was effective in improving the durability of mortar. Moreover, for enhancing the strength, sulphate resistance and carbonation resistance, 1% NS was almost as good as 10% MS and the combined addition of MS and NS showed certain synergistic effects in the sense that the combined effects were larger than the respective sums of the individual effects. However, for enhancing the chloride resistance and water resistance, 1%–2% NS was less effective compared to 10% MS probably because the filling effect of 1%–2% NS was not as good as that of 10% MS. These results suggest that NS should not be added alone but should be added together with MS for best overall performance.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Micro-silica (MS), also called silica fume, is a by-product of the production of silicon or silicon alloys [1]. It contains high purity of silica (>80%) in amorphous form and generally has particle size ranging from 0.1 to 0.5 lm and nitrogen BET surface of about 20,000 m2/kg [2,3]. Throughout the years, MS has become one of the most popular supplementary cementitious materials used in the production of high-strength concrete and high-performance concrete [4–8]. On the other hand, various types of nano-materials have been brought in by the recent advent of nanotechnology, which
is commonly defined as the control of matter based on moleculeby-molecule manipulation [9]. Some of these nano-materials may have good applications in civil engineering, especially concrete materials [10–13]. Among them, nano-silica (NS), which can be produced by the sol–gel process, vaporization method, biological method or precipitation method [14–17] and contains very high purity of silica (>90%) with ultra-high fineness [18], is one of the most attractive nano-materials for further advancement of concrete technology [19–24].
It is well known that MS is a good supplementary cementitious material for improving the durability of concrete structures. For instance, Mardani-Aghabaglou et al. [25] compared the effectiveness of fly ash, metakaolin and MS in enhancing the mechanical properties and durability performance of mortar and pointed out that among these supplementary cementitious materials, MS is the best. Gesoğlu et al. [26] made self-compacting concretes with binary, ternary and quaternary blends of cement, fly ash, slag and MS, and revealed that in terms of durability performance, the ternary blend of cement, slag and MS is the best combination. Farahani et al. [27] applied MS to produce marine concrete and have developed a mathematical model to predict the long-term chloride diffusion in concrete containing MS. Gupta et al. [28] explored the feasibility of using waste rubber fiber in concrete and found that the reductions in strength and water resistance due to the use of waste rubber fiber can be compensated by increasing the MS content.
In recent years, some studies on the effects of NS on concrete durability have been launched. Early in 2005, Ji [29] carried out a preliminary study on the water permeability and microstructure of concrete containing NS and found that addition of NS can improve the water penetration resistance and make the microstructure more uniform and compact. In 2012, Said et al. [30] investigated the effect of colloidal NS on concretes incorporating cement only or cement + fly ash, and revealed that the addition of NS can significantly improve the chloride resistance. In 2013, Beigi et al. [31] added NS and different fibers to selfconsolidating concrete and showed that NS has great positive effects on reducing water absorption and chloride penetration of self-consolidating fiber-reinforced concrete. In 2016, Wu et al. [32] used NS in ultra-high strength concrete and pointed out that there exists an optimal NS content of about 1% for minimizing the porosity of concrete.
Meanwhile, some researchers investigated the effects of combined addition of MS and NS. For instance, in 2012, Jalal et al. [33] tried the addition of MS only, NS only and blended MS + NS, and found that the blending of 10% MS + 2% NS would lead to the highest strength and lowest water absorption, capillary absorption and chloride penetration. In 2014, Zapata-Ordúz et al. [34] made concrete containing cement, fly ash, MS and NS in binary, ternary and quaternary mixing for split tensile strength test, and applied Weibull distribution to analyze the tensile strength results. In 2016, Shaikh et al. [35] studied the effects of MS and NS on bond behaviour of steel and polypropylene fiber reinforced mortar with high volume of fly ash, and showed that the combined use of 10% MS + 2% NS would improve the pull-out strength to higher than those with only 10% MS added or only 2% NS added. In 2017, Li et al. [36] proved that the addition of both MS and NS has synergistic effects on strength and microstructure of mortar. Nevertheless, comprehensive research on the combined effects of MS and NS on the durability performance of various kinds of concrete is still lacking.
In the study presented herein, in order to investigate the combined effects of MS and NS on the durability of mortar or the mortar portion of concrete, a number of mortar mixes with various water, MS and NS contents were produced for strength, sulphate resistance, carbonation resistance, chloride resistance and water
resistance tests. For each mortar mix, the superplasticizer dosage was adjusted to achieve a constant workability. Based on the results so obtained, the effects of adding MS alone, NS alone, and MS and NS together on durability are evaluated, and the possible synergistic effects of combined addition of MS and NS are studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
In this study, cement, MS and NS were used as the cementitious materials. The cement used was an ordinary Portland cement (OPC) of strength class 52.5N, which had been tested to comply with BS EN 197-1: 2011. The MS used was a condensed silica fume imported from Europe, which had been tested by the supplier to comply with ASTM C1240-15. The NS used was a powder form nano-silica manufactured in China with particle size ranging from 5 to 20 nm and purity higher than 99.6%. Scanning electron microscope image of the MS particles and transmission electron microscopy image of the NS particles are presented in Fig. 1(a) and (b), respectively, from which the particle sizes and shapes can be clearly seen. Regarding the fine aggregate, natural river sand with maximum size of 1.18 mm, moisture content of 0.21% and water absorption of 1.1% was used. The relative densities of the OPC, MS, NS and fine aggregate were measured as 3.11, 2.20, 1.94, and 2.58, respectively. A laser diffraction particle size analyzer was used to measure the particle size distributions of the OPC and MS, while the mechanical sieving method was used to measure the particle size distribution of the fine aggregate. The particle size distributions so obtained are plotted in Fig. 2.
On the other hand, the superplasticizer (SP) added to the mortar mixes was a polycarboxylate-based type with a solid mass content of 20% and a relative density of 1.03. It is a commonly used SP for production of high-performance concrete.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mix proportions
sections.text:
To investigate the effects of MS and NS, an experimental program was launched, in which mortar mixes with different water to cementitious materials (W/CM) ratios, MS and NS contents (each expressed as a percentage by mass of total cementitious materials) and SP dosages (each in terms of liquid mass of SP expressed as a percentage by mass of total cementitious materials) were tested. The cementitious paste volume (solid volume of cementitious materials + liquid volume of water, expressed as a percentage of total volume of mortar) was fixed at 60%, while the W/CM ratio by mass was varied among 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, and 0.40, the MS content was varied between 0% and 10%, and the NS content was varied among 0%, 1%, and 2%. As there were four different W/CM ratios, two different MS contents and three different NS contents, a total of 4 2 3 = 24 mortar mixes were produced for testing.
Each mortar mix was assigned an identification code of X-Y-Z, in which X denotes the W/CM ratio, Y denotes the MS content (%) and Z denotes the NS content (%), as listed in the first columns of Tables 1 and 2. Unlike the other mix parameters, the SP dosage in each mortar mix was not fixed but determined by trial mixing, during which the SP was added to the mortar mix in small increments until a flow spread of at least 200 mm was achieved (such workability should be good enough for proper mixing and compaction of the concrete produced).

sections.heading: 2.3. Mini slump flow test
sections.text:
The workability of each mortar mix was measured in terms of flow spread by the mini slump flow test for mortar, which may
be regarded as a reduced scale version of the slump flow test for concrete. The version of slump cone adopted was the same as that developed by Okamura and Ouchi [37]. It has a base diameter of 100 mm, a top diameter of 70 mm and a height of 60 mm. During
the test, the flow spread was determined as the average of two perpendicular diameters of the mortar patty formed. The authors have been using this test in their previous research and further details of the test can be found in a paper by Li and Kwan [38].

sections.heading: 2.4. Sulphate attack test
sections.text: Each mortar mix was tested for its sulphate resistance by the sulphate attack test stipulated in the Chinese Standard GB/T 50082-2009 [39]. To perform the test, six 100 mm cube specimens were made and cured in lime-saturated water at a temperature of 20 ± 2 C until the age of 26 days. After curing, three of the six specimens were transferred to a drying chamber at a temperature of 80 C for 48 h. After drying, the specimens were cooled down to room temperature and placed into a sulphate attack testing machine, as shown in Fig. 3(a), for 90 days. In the testing machine, the specimens were subjected to one wetting–drying cycle (immersion in 5.0% sodium sulphate (Na2SO4) solution for 15 h + air drying for 1 h + 80 C heated drying for 6 h + cooling down for 2 h) every day. After the 90 cycles at the age of 118 days (28 days + 90 days), the specimens were tested for their cube strengths and the average cube strength was taken as the cube strength after sulphate attack. In the meantime, the other three of the six specimens were continuously cured in lime-saturated water until the age of 28 days and thereafter left to dry for 90 days. Then, these specimens were tested for their cube strengths and the average cube strength was taken as the cube strength without sulphate attack. The strength loss after sulphate attack, calculated as (1.0 minus the ratio of strength after sulphate attack to strength without sulphate attack) times 100%, was taken as a measure of the effect of sulphate attack.

sections.heading: 2.5. Carbonation test
sections.text: Each mortar mix was tested for its carbonation resistance by the carbonation test stipulated in the Chinese Standard GB/T 50082- 2009 [39]. To perform the test, three 100 mm cube specimens were made and cured in lime-saturated water at a temperature of 20 ± 2 C until the age of 26 days, and then transferred to a drying chamber at a temperature of 60 C for 48 h. After drying, the cube specimens were cooled down to room temperature and each sealed at five faces with paraffin. After sealing, the specimens were placed into a carbonation chamber, as shown in Fig. 3(b), in which the temperature was controlled at 20 ± 2 C, the relative humidity was controlled at 70 ± 5% and the carbon dioxide concentration was controlled at 20 ± 3%. After 28 days of carbonation, the specimens were split and sprayed with 1% phenolphthalein alcohol solution. The average perpendicular depth to the pink area was taken as the carbonation depth.

sections.heading: 2.6. Rapid chloride permeability test
sections.text:
Each mortar mix was tested for its chloride resistance by the rapid chloride permeability test (RCPT) stipulated in the Chinese Standard GB/T 50082-2009 [39]. To perform the test, three cylinder specimens with 100 mm diameter and 50 mm height were made and cured in lime-saturated water for 28 days. After curing, the specimens were first brushed on the side surfaces with a rapid setting coating and when the coating had dried up, the specimens were placed into a vacuum desiccator at an absolute pressure of 1 5 kPa for 3 h, then pre-boiled water was added into the vacuum desiccator to immerse the specimens at vacuum pressure for 1 h and then at atmospheric pressure for 18 ± 2 h. After such treatment, the cylinder specimens were mounted to the voltage cells. The positive reservoir of each cell was filled with 0.3 mol/L sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution, while the negative reservoir

sections.heading: 2.7. Water absorption test
sections.text:
Each mortar mix was tested for its water resistance by the water absorption test stipulated in the American Standard ASTM C1585-04 [40]. To perform the test, three cylinder specimens with 100 mm diameter and 50 mm height were made and cured in lime-saturated water for 28 days. After curing, the specimens were placed into an environmental chamber at a temperature of 50 ± 2 C and a relative humidity of 80 ± 3% for 3 days. After the 3 days, each specimen was moved to a separate sealable container, inside which the temperature was kept at 23 ± 2 C for 15 days. Before the water absorption test, each specimen was first brushed on the side surface with epoxy resin and sealed at one end, which would not be exposed to water, with a loosely attached plastic sheet, as shown in Fig.3(d).
During the water absorption test, the test surface of the specimen was placed into a water tank, as shown in Fig.3(d), and the increase in mass of the specimen at various times after the water absorption test was determined using an electronic balance. From the increase in mass at time t after the start of water absorption (denoted by mt) and the area of inflow surface (denoted by a), the water absorption at time t (the absorbed volume of water per unit area of inflow surface, denoted by I) can be calculated as I = (mt/q)/a, where q is the density of water. In general, the water absorption would increase as a square root function of the time t after the start of the test. Therefore, the absorption rate is defined as the slope of the line that is the best fit to I plotted against the square root of time t1/2. The initial absorption rate can be determined by linear regression analysis using all the data points from
1 min to 6 h, whereas the secondary absorption rate can be determined by linear regression analysis using all the data points from 1 day to 7 days.

sections.heading: 3.1. SP dosage
sections.text:
During mixing, a mortar mix with lower W/CM ratio or higher MS and NS contents generally appeared to be drier and more cohesive. Therefore, the SP dosage needed for the mortar mix to achieve the required flow spread of at least 200 mm increased as theW/CM ratio decreased or the MS and NS contents increased. The SP dosages for the mortar mixes to attain the required flow spread, i.e. the SP demands, are listed in the second column of Table 1.
From Table 1, it can be seen that as the W/CM ratio decreased from 0.40 to 0.25, the SP dosage increased dramatically. This is expected because a mortar mix with a lower W/CM ratio would generally require more SP to maintain the same workability. More importantly, the SP dosage increased substantially with the MS and NS contents. For instance, at a W/CM ratio of 0.40, the SP dosage increased from 0.3% to 1.2% by about 3.0 times when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and increased from 0.3% to 1.7% by about 4.7 times when the NS content increased from 0% to 2%. At a W/CM ratio of 0.25, the SP dosage increased from 2.2% to 4.5% by about 1.0 times when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and increased from 2.2% to 4.8% by about 1.2 times when the NS content increased from 0% to 2%. Overall, the increase in SP dosage with the MS or NS content was proportionally smaller at a lower W/CM ratio.

In fact, although not quantified, it was felt by finger touching during the mortar mixing that a mortar sample containing a higher MS or NS content was generally more cohesive.

sections.heading: 3.3. Cracking and cube strength after sulphate attack
sections.text:
The photographs of the specimens cast from the mixes 0.40-0-0, 0.40-10-0, 0.40-0-2, and 0.40-10-2 (W/CM = 0.40 and containing 0% MS + 0% NS, 10% MS + 0% NS, 0% MS + 2% NS, and 10% MS + 2% NS) after 90 days of sulphate attack are shown in Fig. 4(a), (b), (c) a nd (d), respectively. From Fig. 4(a), it can be seen that without MS and NS added, fairly large cracks were formed on the surface of the specimen and some corners of the specimen have been corroded away. With 10% MS added, as shown in Fig. 4(b), some medium cracks and many small cracks were formed on the surface of the specimen. With 2% NS added, as shown in Fig. 4(c), only medium cracks were formed on the surface of the specimen. In contrast, with 10% MS and 2% NS added, as shown in Fig. 4(d), only small cracks were formed. These photographs illustrate that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in reducing crack formation under sulphate attack.
The cube strength results without sulphate attack and after sulphate attack are tabulated in the fourth and fifth columns of Table 1, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Fig.5(a) and (b), respectively. From these results, it is obvious that the cube strengths under different conditions all increased as the W/CM ratio decreased. Such observed phenomenon is expected because the strength is generally higher at a lower W/CM ratio. Besides, it is seen from Fig.5(a) and (b) that the cube strength-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is
generally higher than that of a mortar with 0% MS and the cube strength-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is generally higher than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the cube strength curves upwards as the MS or NS content increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the compressive strength of mortar. Of particular interest is that the cube strength curves for (0% MS + 1% NS) and (10% MS + 0% NS) are very close to each other, revealing that for enhancing strength, 1% NS is almost as good as 10% MS.
More importantly, comparing the cube strength after sulphate attack with the cube strength without sulphate attack, it is noted that the cube strength after sulphate attack was always lower than the cube strength without sulphate attack. This was due to the corrosive effect of the sulphate. To evaluate the sulphate resistance of the mortar, the strength losses after sulphate attack were calculated, tabulated in the sixth column of Table 1, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Fig. 6. From these results, it is evident that the strength loss decreased as the W/CM ratio decreased. This is expected because the sulphate resistance is generally higher at a lower W/CM ratio. Notably, the strength lossW/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is generally lower than that of a mortar with 0% MS and the strength loss-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is generally lower than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the strength loss curves downwards as the MS or NS content increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the sulphate resistance of mortar. Particularly, the strength loss curves for (0% MS + 1% NS) and (10% MS + 0% NS) almost coincide with each other, revealing that for enhancing sulphate resistance, 1% NS is almost as good as 10% MS.

sections.heading: 3.4. Carbonation depth
sections.text:
The carbonation depth results are tabulated in the second column of Table 2, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Fig. 7. From these results, it is noted that the carbonation depth decreased as the W/CM ratio decreased. Such
observed phenomenon is expected because the carbonation resistance is generally higher at a lowerW/CM ratio. It is also noted that the carbonation depth-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is generally lower than that of a mortar with 0% MS and the carbonation depth-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is generally lower than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the carbonation depth curves downwards as the MS or NS content increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the carbonation resistance of mortar. Moreover, the carbonation depth curves for (0% MS + 1% NS) and (10% MS + 0% NS) almost coincide with each other, revealing that for enhancing carbonation resistance, 1% NS is almost as good as 10% MS.

sections.heading: 3.5. RCPT total charge passed
sections.text:
The RCPT total charge passed results are tabulated in the third column of Table 2, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Fig. 8. From these results, it is found that the total charge passed decreased as the W/CM ratio decreased. Such observed phenomenon is expected because the chloride resistance is generally higher at a lower W/CM ratio. It is also found that the total charge passed-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is substantially lower than that of a mortar with 0% MS and that the total charge passed-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is slightly lower than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the total charge passed curves downwards as the MS or NS content increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the chloride resistance of mortar.
However, it appears that NS was much less effective compared to MS in enhancing the chloride resistance. For instance, at a W/CM ratio of 0.40, the total charge passed decreased from 6821 to 537 coulomb by 92.1% when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and decreased from 6821 to 6575 coulomb by only 3.6% when
the NS content increased from 0% to 1%. At a W/CM ratio of 0.25, the total charge passed decreased from 2958 to 115 coulomb by 96.1% when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and decreased from 2958 to 2601 coulomb by only 12.1% when the NS content increased from 0% to 1%. Even a higher NS content of 2% NS was much less effective than 10% MS in enhancing the chloride resistance. This was probably because the filling effect of the relatively small quantity of 1%–2% NS was not as good as that of 10% MS.

sections.heading: 3.6. Water absorption rate
sections.text:
The initial water absorption rate and secondary water absorption rate are tabulated in the fourth and fifth columns of Table 2, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Figs. 9 and 10, respectively. From these results, it is evident that the initial and secondary water absorption rates all decreased as theW/CM ratio decreased. Such observed phenomenon is expected because the water resistance is generally higher at a lower W/CM ratio. It is also evident that the water absorption rate-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is generally lower than that of a mortar with 0% MS and the water absorption rate-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is generally lower than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the water absorption curves downwards as the MS or NS content increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the water resistance of mortar.
However, it appears that NS was less effective compared to MS in enhancing the water resistance. For instance, at a W/CM ratio of 0.40, the initial water absorption rate decreased from 24.1 to 11.7 10 4 mm/s1/2 by 51.5% when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and decreased from 24.1 to 17.8 10 4 mm/s1/2 by only 26.1% when the NS content increased from 0% to 1%. At a W/CM ratio of 0.25, the initial water absorption rate decreased from 8.2 to 2.6 10 4 mm/s1/2 by 68.3% when the MS content increased
from 0% to 10%, and decreased from 8.2 to 6.0 10 4 mm/s1/2 by only 26.8% when the NS content increased from 0% to 2%. Even a higher NS content of 2% NS was less effective than 10% MS in enhancing the water resistance. These observations apply also to the secondary water absorption rate. The small effectiveness of NS was probably because the filling effect of the relatively small quantity of 1% to 2% NS was not as good as that of 10% MS.

sections.heading: 4. Combined effects of MS and NS
4.1. Combined effects of MS and NS on strength
sections.text:
The percentage increases in cube strength (cube strength without sulphate attack) due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Table 3. In the table, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage increases in strength due to the addition of 10% MS only, addition of 1% NS only and addition of 2% NS only. These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the additions of 10% MS or 1% NS or 2% NS are all effective in enhancing the strength. On the other hand, the fifth and sixth rows depict the percentage increases in strength due to the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) and combined addition of (10% MS + 2% NS). These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) would increase the strength by a percentage larger than the sum of the percentage increase in strength due to addition of 10% MS only and the percentage increase in strength due to addition of 1% NS only. Likewise, at all W/CM ratios, the combined addition
of (10% MS + 2% NS) would increase the strength by a percentage larger than the sum of the percentage increase in strength due to addition of 10% MS only and the percentage increase in strength due to addition of 2% NS only. Hence, when added together, MS and NS have certain synergistic effect on the strength in the sense that the combined effect of MS and NS is larger than the sum of the individual effects.

sections.heading: 4.2. Combined effects of MS and NS on sulphate resistance
sections.text: The percentage decreases in strength loss after sulphate attack due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Table 4. In the table, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage decreases in strength loss due to the addition of 10% MS only, addition of 1% NS only and addition of 2% NS only, while the fifth and sixth rows depict the percentage decreases in strength loss due to the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) and combined addition of (10% MS + 2% NS). These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the additions of 10% MS or 1% NS or 2% NS are all effective in enhancing the sulphate resistance. Moreover, at all W/CM ratios, the combined addition of MS and NS would decrease the strength loss by a percentage larger than the sum of the percentage decrease in strength loss due to addition of MS only and the percentage decrease in strength loss due to addition of NS only. Hence, when added together, MS and NS have certain synergistic effect on the sulphate resistance in the sense that the combined effect of MS and NS is larger than the sum of the individual effects.

sections.heading: 4.3. Combined effects of MS and NS on carbonation resistance
sections.text:
The percentage decreases in carbonation depth due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Table 5. In the table, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage decreases in carbonation depth due to the addition of 10% MS only, addition of 1% NS only
and addition of 2% NS only, while the fifth and sixth rows depict the percentage decreases in carbonation depth due to the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) and combined addition of (10% MS + 2% NS). These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the additions of 10% MS or 1% NS or 2% NS are all effective in
enhancing the carbonation resistance. Moreover, at all W/CM ratios, the combined addition of MS and NS would decrease the carbonation depth by a percentage larger than the sum of the percentage decrease in carbonation depth due to addition of MS only and the percentage decrease in carbonation depth due to addition of NS only. Hence, when added together, MS and NS have certain synergistic effect on the carbonation resistance in the sense that the combined effect of MS and NS is larger than the sum of the individual effects.

sections.heading: 4.4. Combined effects of MS and NS on chloride resistance
sections.text: The percentage decreases in RCPT total charge passed due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Table 6. In the table, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage decreases in RCPT total charge passed due to the addition of 10% MS only, addition of 1% NS only and addition of 2% NS only. These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the addition of 10% MS would dramatically reduce the RCPT total charge passed by more than 90% but the addition of 1%–2% NS would only reduce the RCPT total charge passed by several percent to at most about 30%. On the other hand, the fifth and sixth rows depict the percentage decreases in RCPT total charge passed due to the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) and combined addition of (10% MS + 2% NS). These results reveal that after the addition of 10% MS, the further addition of 1%–2% NS produced fairly small further reduction in RCPT total charge passed. As a result, the combined addition of MS and NS has no synergistic effect on the chloride resistance.

sections.heading: 4.5. Combined effects of MS and NS on water resistance
sections.text:
The percentage decreases in initial water absorption rate due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Table 7. In the table, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage decreases in initial
water absorption rate due to the addition of 10% MS only, addition of 1% NS only and addition of 2% NS only. These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios, the addition of 10% MS would reduce the initial water absorption rate by more than 50% but the addition of 1%–2% NS would only reduce the initial water absorption rate by less than 50%. On the other hand, the fifth and sixth rows depict the percentage decreases in initial water absorption rate due to the combined addition of (10% MS + 1% NS) and combined addition of (10% MS + 2% NS). These results reveal that the combined addition of MS and NS has no synergistic effect on the water resistance. Nevertheless, the decrease in water absorption rate due to the combined addition of MS and NS was always larger than that due to the addition of MS alone and that due to the addition of NS alone. In other words, the combined addition of MS and NS would allow the water resistance to be further increased to higher than that achievable by adding MS or NS alone.

sections.heading: 5. Effectiveness of MS and NS
sections.text:
At this stage, it would appear that the following are the possible causes of the combined effects of MS and NS on strength and durability. Firstly, being composed mainly of high purity silica, both MS and NS have the pozzolanic effect of reacting with the calcium hydroxide liberated during cement hydration to produce further C-S-H gel, which contributes to increase both the strength and corrosion resistance [41,42]. Relatively, because of its larger surface area, NS is more reactive than MS and that is why a small amount of NS can be as good as 10% MS in enhancing strength, sulphate resistance and carbonation resistance.
Secondly, since MS is finer than cement and NS is finer than MS, both MS and NS have the filling effect of filling into the voids between cement grains to increase the packing density of the powder content and densify the microstructure. This would reduce the permeability and thus prevent the penetration of deleterious materials [43,44]. However, when NS is used, only 1%–2% would be sufficient and thus the volume of NS added would be relatively small compared that of MS. Because of the small volume of NS added, the filling effect of NS is not as good as that of MS. As a result, 1%–2% NS is not as effective as 10% MS in enhancing the chloride resistance and water resistance.
It is advocated herein that NS should not be added alone but should be added together with MS so that the MS would fill into the voids between cement grains and the NS would fill into the voids between the particles in the cement + MS mixture. This is the best way to utilize the good filling effect of MS and the high pozzolanic reactivity of the NS. In fact, the combined addition of MS and NS would offer the added advantage of certain synergistic effects on strength, sulphate resistance and carbonation resistance. Even without synergistic effects, the combined addition of MS and NS would allow the chloride resistance and water resistance to be further increased to higher than those achievable by adding MS or NS alone.
Finally, the above beneficial effects are attainable only if the concrete mix has good enough workability to be properly

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
To study the combined use of MS and NS in concrete and to evaluate the effectiveness of adding MS alone, adding NS alone and adding MS + NS together in enhancing the durability of concrete, a series of mortar mixes with varying W/CM ratio, MS content and NS content but more or less the same workability were made for flow spread measurement, cube strength measurement, sulphate attack test, carbonation test, rapid chloride permeability test and water absorption test. Based on the test results, the following conclusions are drawn:
(1) The additions of MS and NS would significantly increase the SP demand of mortar for maintaining good workability. (2) The additions of MS and/or NS would significantly increase the cube strength, sulphate resistance and carbonation resistance of mortar. Basically, the addition of just 1% NS is
almost as good as the addition of 10% MS, and the combined addition of MS and NS could offer certain synergistic effects in the sense that the combined effects of MS and NS are larger than the respective sums of the individual effects of MS and NS. (3) The additions of MS and/or NS would significantly improve the chloride resistance and water resistance of mortar. Somehow, the addition of 1%–2% NS is not as effective as the addition of 10% MS probably because the filling effect of the relatively small volume of 1%–2% NS is not as good as that of 10% MS. Furthermore, the combined addition of MS and NS would not offer any synergistic effect. Nevertheless, the combined addition of MS and NS would allow the chloride resistance and water resistance to be further increased to higher than those achievable by adding MS or NS alone. (4) NS should not be added alone but should be added together with MS so that the MS and NS would successively fill into the voids to increase the packing density of the cementitious materials and densify the microstructure of hardened
cementitious paste. This is the best way to utilize the good filling effect of MS and the high pozzolanic reactivity of the NS so as to further increase the strength and durability of concrete for the production of the next generation highperformance concrete.

Among them, nano-silica (NS), which can be produced by the sol–gel process, vaporization method, biological method or precipitation method [14–17] and contains very high purity of silica (>90%) with ultra-high fineness [18], is one of the most attractive nano-materials for further advancement of concrete technology [19–24].

[25] compared the effectiveness of fly ash, metakaolin and MS in enhancing the mechanical properties and durability performance of mortar and pointed out that among these supplementary cementitious materials, MS is the best.

[26] made self-compacting concretes with binary, ternary and quaternary blends of cement, fly ash, slag and MS, and revealed that in terms of durability performance, the ternary blend of cement, slag and MS is the best combination.
[27] applied MS to produce marine concrete and have developed a mathematical model to predict the long-term chloride diffusion in concrete containing MS.

[28] explored the feasibility of using waste rubber fiber in concrete and found that the reductions in strength and water resistance due to the use of waste rubber fiber can be compensated by increasing the MS content.

Early in 2005, Ji [29] carried out a preliminary study on the water permeability and microstructure of concrete containing NS and found that addition of NS can improve the water penetration resistance and make the microstructure more uniform and compact.
[30] investigated the effect of colloidal NS on concretes incorporating cement only or cement + fly ash, and revealed that the addition of NS can significantly improve the chloride resistance.

[31] added NS and different fibers to selfconsolidating concrete and showed that NS has great positive effects on reducing water absorption and chloride penetration of self-consolidating fiber-reinforced concrete.
[32] used NS in ultra-high strength concrete and pointed out that there exists an optimal NS content of about 1% for minimizing the porosity of concrete.

[33] tried the addition of MS only, NS only and blended MS + NS, and found that the blending of 10% MS + 2% NS would lead to the highest strength and lowest water absorption, capillary absorption and chloride penetration.

[34] made concrete containing cement, fly ash, MS and NS in binary, ternary and quaternary mixing for split tensile strength test, and applied Weibull distribution to analyze the tensile strength results.

[35] studied the effects of MS and NS on bond behaviour of steel and polypropylene fiber reinforced mortar with high volume of fly ash, and showed that the combined use of 10% MS + 2% NS would improve the pull-out strength to higher than those with only 10% MS added or only 2% NS added.
